en.value: The writer found in his wife a:
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the questions/complete the statements that follow by choosing the correct options out of the given ones.

I married early, and was happy to find in my wife a disposition not very dissimilar to my own temperament. Observing my partiality for having pets at home, she lost no opportunity of procuring those of the most agreeable kind. We had birds, gold-fish, a fine dog, rabbits, a small monkey, and a cat.

This latter was a remarkably large and beautiful animal, entirely black, observant and thoughtful to an astonishing degree. In speaking of his intelligence, my wife, who at heart was not a little superstitions, made frequent allusions to the ancient popular notion, which regarded all black cats as witches in disguise. Not that she was ever serious upon this point - and I mention the matter at all for no reason than that it happens, just now, to be remembered.

Pluto - this was the cat's name - was my favourite pet and playmate. I alone fed him, and he attended me wherever I went about the house. It was even with difficulty that I could prevent him from following me through the streets.

Our friendship lasted, in this manner, for many years, during which my general temperament underwent a change for the worse. I grew, day by day, more moody, more irritable, more regardless of the feeling of others. I suffered myself to use foul language to my wife. At length I offered her violence. My pets, of course, were made to feel the change in my behaviour. I not only neglected, but ill-used them. For Pluto, however, I still retained sufficient regard to 'restrain' me from maltreating him. But my disease grew upon me - for what disease is like Alcohol! And at length even Pluto, who was now becoming old and somewhat peevish - even Pluto began to experience the effects of my ill temper.

options.value: lady belonging to a noble family.
lady with a similar taste and temperament.

en.value: A teacher of class VI found in her classroom there are about seven languages. She uses the languages of learners to teach-learn languages and content subject. What is the strategy known as?
What did Tribhuvandas Patel do to the milk lake of Kaira?
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the questions/complete the statements that follow by choosing the correct options out of the given ones.

Initially the milk lake of Kaira district in Anand in Gujarat was still. The cooperative movement led by Tribhuvandas Patel, under the guidance of Sardar Patel began to stir that lake. In due course of time it overflowed and start spreading throughout the country. All this would not have been possible without the steady presence of Dr Kurien. Incidentally, Dr Kurien first came to work with the Dairy Research Institute in 1949, which became an integral part of the stream of milk consciousness. He took over an already existing dairy cooperative, run by Tribhuvandas Patel and mobilised the Milk Producers' cooperatives, after office hours. He totally transformed the concept of dairying, by making the entire programme as comprehensive as possible with innovative methods such as having a network of veterinary services and cattle breeding centres.

India's Dairy Development Programme started in an era of acute milk shortage, when milk powder and butter oil were gifted to India, by the World Food Organisation, which subsequently emerged as a tremendous success. 'Operation Flood', a dairy cooperative system evolved by Dr Kurien on a national scale, has steered the country from milk scarcity to surplus, for other milk products. Under the umbrella of the National Dairy Development Board, 6 million dairy owners in 75,000 villages and milk producers' cooperative societies have been producing and marketing milk to 500 cities and towns, throughout India.

options.value: <span style="">He supplied the milk all over India.</span>
<span style="">He turned it into milk powder.</span>
<span style="">He started it to make butter.</span>

He totally transformed the concept of dairying, by making the entire programme as comprehensive as possible with innovative methods such as having a network of veterinary services and cattle breeding centres.

India's Dairy Development Programme started in an era of acute milk shortage, when milk powder and butter oil were gifted to India, by the World Food Organisation, which subsequently emerged as a tremendous success. 'Operation Flood', a dairy cooperative system evolved by Dr Kurien on a national scale, has steered the country from milk scarcity to surplus, for other milk products. Under the umbrella of the National Dairy Development Board, 6 million dairy owners in 75,000 villages and milk producers' cooperative societies have been producing and marketing milk to 500 cities and towns, throughout India.

en.value: On receiving the invitation the old man was overjoyed as:
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the questions/complete the statements that follow by choosing the correct options out of the given ones.

The old man was overjoyed when he heard of the invitation. He became nearly incoherent with joy. He was torn between the attraction of the offer and shyness. For the first time Srinivas observed that the man could be moved by shyness. "No, no, I never eat anywhere. Oh, don't trouble yourself about it... No, no ..." he said' but all the same got up and followed Srinivas into the kitchen. He grinned affably at Srinivas's wife and commented flatteringly: "I have always told a lot of people to come and observe this lady for a model. How well she looks after the house. I wish modern girls were all like her." Srinivas gently propelled him to a plank, on which he sat down. He observed from his wife's face that she was pleased with the compliment, and Srinivas felt that old man's coffee was now assured. His wife came out with a tumbler of water and two leaves and set them in front of them. She then served a couple of cakes on each leaf, and the old man rubbed his hands with the joy of anticipation.

At a signal from Srinivas he fell to; and Srinivas wondered how long it was since the other had had any. "What do you eat at nights?" he asked testingly. The old man tore off a piece of cake and stuffed it in his mouth and swallowed it before he answered, shaking his head: 'I'm not a youth. Time was when I used to take three meals a day - three full meals a day in addition to tiffin twice a day. Do you know __________"

"That's remarkable." Agreed Srinivas admiringly. "But now what do you do?"

"I'm a sanyasi, my dear young man."
